tn.text: "Do not take"
"Go right away"

This was another name for the region of Mesopotamia, which about the same location as modern Iraq. See how this was translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:25:19|25:20]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This refers to a person's descendants or other relatives. AT: "family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Bethuel was Rebekah's father. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:22:20|22:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"your grandfather"
"from the daughters"
"your uncle"
Isaac continues speaking to Jacob

tn.ref: make you fruitful and multiply you
tn.text: The word "multiply" explains how God would make Jacob "fruitful." AT: "give you many children and descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: May he give you the blessing of Abraham, to you, and to your descendants after you
tn.text: This speaks about blessing someone as if a blessing were an object that a person can give. The abstract noun "the blessing" can be stated as "bless." AT: "May God bless you and your descendants as he blessed Abraham" or "May God give to you and your descendants what he promised to Abraham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: that you may inherit the land
tn.text: God giving the land of Canaan to Jacob and his descendants is spoken of as if a child were inheriting money or possessions from his father. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the land where you have been living
tn.text: "the land where you have been staying"
"which God promised to Abraham"

This was another name for the region of Mesopotamia, which about the same location as modern Iraq. See how this was translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:25:19|25:20]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Bethuel was Rebekah's father. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:22:20|22:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The story changes from Jacob to Esau
This word is used here to mark a change from the story to background information about Esau. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

This was another name for the region of Mesopotamia, which about the same location as modern Iraq. See how this was translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:25:19|25:20]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"to take a wife for himself"

tn.ref: He also saw that Isaac had blessed him
tn.text: "Esau also saw that Isaac had blessed Jacob"
"Do not take"
"daughters of Canaan" or "Canaanite women"
This continues the background information about Esau.
"Esau realized"

tn.ref: the women of Canaan did not please Isaac his father
tn.text: "his father Isaac did not approve of the women of Canaan"
"daughters of Canaan" or "the Canaanite women"
"Because of that"

tn.ref: besides the wives that he had
tn.text: "in addition to the wives that he already had"
This is the name of one of Ishmael's daughters. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of one of Ishmael's sons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The story switches back to Jacob

tn.ref: He came to a certain place and stayed there all night, because the sun had set
tn.text: "He came to a certain place and, because the sun had set, he decided to stay for the night"
"Jacob had a dream"
"with the bottom of it touching the ground"
This refers to the place where God lives.
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.
Possible meanings are 1) "Yahweh was standing at the top of the stairway" or 2) "Yahweh was standing next to Jacob"
Here "father" means "ancestor." AT: "Abraham your ancestor" or "Abraham your forefather"
God continues to talk to Jacob in a dream.

tn.ref: Your descendants will be like the dust of the earth
tn.text: God compares Jacob's descendants to the dust of the earth to emphasize their huge number. AT: "You will have more descendants than you can count" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: and you will spread far out to the west
tn.text: Here the word "you" is singular but refers to Jacob's descendants. It only speaks of Jacob since he is the leader of the family. AT: "and your descendants will spread out to the west" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This means the people will extend the borders of their land and occupy more territory.

tn.ref: to the west, to the east, to the north, and to the south
tn.text: This phrases are used together to mean "all directions." AT: "in all directions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Through you and through your descendants will all the families of the earth be blessed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will bless all families on the earth through you and your descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This adds emphasis to what is said next. AT: "Look" or "Listen" or "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you"

tn.ref: for I will not leave you. I will do all
tn.text: "for I will not leave you until I have done all"
"I will keep you safe" or "I will protect you"

tn.ref: I will bring you into this land again
tn.text: "I will bring you back to this land"
"woke up from his sleep"

tn.ref: the house of God ... the gate of heaven
tn.text: The phrase "the gate of heaven" explains that this place is the entrance to "the house of God" and "the entrance to where God lives." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: This is the gate of heaven
tn.text: This speaks about the entrance to the place where God lives as if it were a literal kingdom that had a gate that someone has to open to let people in. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a memorial pillar, that is, simply a large stone or boulder set up on its end.

tn.ref: poured oil upon the top of it
tn.text: This action symbolizes that Jacob is dedicating the pillar to God. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "poured oil on the top of it in order to dedicate the pillar to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Translators may also add a footnote that says "The name Bethel means 'house of God.'"
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"made a vow" or "solemnly promised God"

tn.ref: If God will ... then Yahweh will be my God
tn.text: Jacob is speaking to God in the third person. This can be stated in the second person. AT: "If you will ... then you, Yahweh, will be the God that I will worship" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: on this road on which I am walking
tn.text: This stands for Jacob's journey to find a wife and to return home. AT: "on this journey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: will give me bread to eat
tn.text: Here "bread" stands for food in general. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "house" stands for Jacob's family. AT: "to my father and the rest of my family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This means that the stone will mark the place where God appeared to him and it will be a place where people can worship God. AT: "God's house" or "God's place"
